metadata.case_name: Union of India v. Dhanoswar Roy & Ors.

facts.text: On September 10, 1958, an agreement was entered into between the Government of India and Pakistan called the Indo-Pakistan Agreement. Item No. 3 related to Berubari Union No. 12, a group of villages lying within the territory of India, to be divided so as to give one half area to Pakistan and retain the other half adjacent to India.
Berubari Union No. 12 had an area of 8.75 sq. miles and a population of 10 to 12 thousand residents, situated in the district of Jalpaiguri.
Doubt arose whether implementation of the agreement relating to Berubari Union required legislative action by Parliament under Art. 3 or amendment under Art. 368 or both.

President of India made a reference to Supreme Court under Art. 143(1) for advisory opinion, delivered on March 14, 1960, holding that implementation amounted to cession requiring amendment of Art. 4 and First Schedule under Art. 368.
Parliament enacted the Constitution (Ninth Amendment) Act, 1960 on December 28, 1960 to implement the agreement.

Some inhabitants of Berubari Union filed petition under Art. 226 challenging proposed partition; writ dismissed, appeal to Supreme Court dismissed on August 11, 1965 in Ram Kishore Sen v. Union of India.
On June 11, 1965, respondents filed another petition under Art. 226 before Calcutta High Court challenging validity of proposed demarcation.
Respondent Dhanoswar Roy had 2 acres 64 decimals of khas land in the area; respondents claimed household property, ancestral homes and cultivated lands in Berubari Union No. 12.
Calcutta High Court (D. Basu J.) delivered judgment on December 22, 1967 and January 3, 1968, directing issue of rule nisi on ground No. 3 claiming compensation under Art. 31(2).
Single Judge granted certificate under Art. 132(1) despite Letters Patent appeal to Division Bench.

legal_issues.text: Whether the cession of a territory by India as a result of a treaty with Pakistan would be compulsory acquisition of the property comprised in that territory by the Union of India and attract provisions of Art. 31 of the Constitution.
Whether compensation under Article 31(2) is to be provided before demarcation in implementation of the Constitution (Ninth Amendment) Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Cession is transfer of sovereignty over State territory by owner State to another State; essential attributes of sovereignty include power to cede territory.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Oppenheim's International Law Vol. 1, 8th Edn. at pp. 547, 551

petitioner_arguments.text: Inhabitants of ceded territory become subjects of acquiring State ipso facto; no evidence that Pakistan will not recognise private property rights under international law principles (citing U.S. v. Juan Perchman).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State of Gujarat v. Vora Fiddali (1964) 6 SCR 461; U.S. v. Juan Perchman

petitioner_arguments.text: No transfer of ownership or possession to Union of India; mere change of sovereignty does not attract Art. 31(2); High Court assumed Pakistan would disregard rights without evidence.

respondent_arguments.text: No act of State involved in transfer; entitled to compensation under Art. 31(2) as transfer deprives right to property without provision in Ninth Amendment Act.
Treaty-making power subject to fundamental rights; cession involves compulsory acquisition by Union attracting Art. 31(2); Pakistan can deal with territory as absolute owner disregarding rights.

court_reasoning.text: Preliminary objection noted: Single Judge granting Art. 132(1) certificate improper, depriving benefit of Division Bench; exceptional but still wrong practice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Certificate granted despite Letters Patent appeal.

court_reasoning.text: Cession transfers sovereignty, not property ownership to India; private rights not instantly affected under international law; no evidence Pakistan laws disregard rights.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Assumption that Pakistan will confiscate rights is wrong; principles from Perchman case apply.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 31(2) and 2A require transfer of ownership/possession to 'State' (India under Art. 12); cession to Pakistan is not such transfer.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Mere deprivation without transfer to State does not attract compensation.

court_reasoning.text: Ninth Amendment enacted per Berubari advisory opinion; no impediment to ceding territory.

holdings.text: Cession of territory does not involve compulsory acquisition by Union of India under Art. 31(2); no compensation required as no transfer of property ownership to Union.
High Court judgment erroneous; demarcation can proceed without compensation legislation.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Berubari Union and Exchange of Enclaves (Reference under Art. 143(1))
precedents_cited.relevance: Advisory opinion requiring constitutional amendment for cession.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Kishore Sen v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Dismissed challenge to Ninth Amendment Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: R.D. Agarwala v. Union of India
Union of India v. J.P. Mitter
precedents_cited.relevance: Certificate by single judge only in exceptional cases.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Gujarat v. Vora Fiddali Badruddin Mithibarwala
precedents_cited.relevance: Private rights in acquired territory not enforceable against new sovereign unless recognised.
Private property rights remain undisturbed on change of sovereignty.

precedents_cited.case_name: Charanjit Lal Chowdhury v. Union of India
precedents_cited.relevance: Meaning of 'acquisition': entire title passes to acquirer.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of West Bengal v. Subodh Gopal Bose
precedents_cited.relevance: Wider meaning of acquisition/deprivation pre-Fourth Amendment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dwarkadas Shrinivasa v. Sholapur Spinning Weaving Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Wide concept of acquisition pre-Fourth Amendment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Saghir Ahmed v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Followed Subodh Gopal; superseded by Fourth Amendment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gullapalli Nageswara Rao v. Andhra Pradesh State Road Transport Corp.
precedents_cited.relevance: Effect of Fourth Amendment: acquisition requires transfer to State.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Cession requires amendment under Art. 368 per advisory opinion; Art. 31(2) not attracted as no acquisition/transfer to State.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution (Ninth Amendment) Act, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Implemented Berubari cession; no provision for compensation needed.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution (Fourth Amendment) Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: Clarified acquisition requires transfer to State; mere deprivation insufficient.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment set aside. Held that cession of Berubari territory to Pakistan does not involve compulsory acquisition under Art. 31(2) by Union of India, so no compensation required; demarcation can proceed.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed, writ petition stands dismissed implicitly.

key_quotes.text: "Cession is the transfer of sovereignty over the State territory by the owner State to another State."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines cession distinguishing from property acquisition.

key_quotes.text: "The people change their allegiance... but their relations to each other and their rights of property, remain undisturbed."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Intl law principle that private property survives cession (Perchman).

key_quotes.text: "No property shall be compulsorily acquired... save by authority of a law which provides for compensation..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Art. 31(2); central to holding no acquisition.

key_quotes.text: "Unless the law depriving any person of his property provides for the transfer of the ownership... to the State... it shall not be deemed to provide for compulsory acquisition."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains Art. 31(2A); key to rejecting compensation claim.
